chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
question_plain: State whether the following are true or false. Justify your answer. (i) The value of tan A is always less than 1. (ii) sec A = 12/5 for some value of angle A. (iii) cos A is the abbreviation used for the cosecant of angle A. (iv) cot A is the product of cot and A. (v) sin θ = 4/3 for some angle θ.
question_latex: State whether the following are true or false. Justify your answer. (i) The value of \( \tan A \) is always less than 1. (ii) \( \sec A = \frac{12}{5} \) for some value of angle A. (iii) \( \cos A \) is the abbreviation used for the cosecant of angle A. (iv) \( \cot A \) is the product of cot and A. (v) \( \sin \theta = \frac{4}{3} \) for some angle \( \theta \).
correct_answer_plain: (i) False - tan A can be greater than 1 (e.g., tan 60° = √3). (ii) True - sec A ≥ 1 for acute angles, so 12/5 = 2.4 is valid. (iii) False - cos A is cosine, not cosecant (which is cosec A). (iv) False - cot A is cotangent function, not a product. (v) False - sin θ cannot exceed 1, and 4/3 > 1.
correct_answer_latex: (i) False - \( \tan A \) can be greater than 1 (e.g., \( \tan 60° = \sqrt{3} \)). (ii) True - \( \sec A \geq 1 \) for acute angles, so \( \frac{12}{5} = 2.4 \) is valid. (iii) False - \( \cos A \) is cosine, not cosecant (which is \( \cosec A \)). (iv) False - \( \cot A \) is cotangent function, not a product. (v) False - \( \sin \theta \) cannot exceed 1, and \( \frac{4}{3} > 1 \).
hint: Check range of each trigonometric function and understand their definitions
solution_steps: (i) False: tan A = sin A / cos A. For A = 60°, tan 60° = √3 ≈ 1.732 > 1
(ii) True: sec A = 1/cos A. For acute angles, cos A ≤ 1, so sec A ≥ 1. Since 12/5 = 2.4 > 1, it is possible
(iii) False: cos A stands for cosine of A. Cosecant is abbreviated as cosec A or csc A
(iv) False: cot A is the cotangent function of angle A, not multiplication of 'cot' and 'A'
(v) False: For any angle θ, -1 ≤ sin θ ≤ 1. Since 4/3 ≈ 1.33 > 1, sin θ = 4/3 is impossible

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
section: 8.3 Trigonometric Ratios of Some Specific Angles
question_plain: Choose the correct option and justify your choice: (i) (2 tan 30°)/(1 - tan²30°) = (A) sin 60° (B) cos 60° (C) tan 60° (D) sin 30° (ii) (1 - tan²45°)/(1 + tan²45°) = (A) tan 90° (B) 1 (C) sin 45° (D) 0 (iii) sin 2A = 2 sin A is true when A = (A) 0° (B) 30° (C) 45° (D) 60° (iv) (2 tan 30°)/(1 - tan²30°) = (A) cos 60° (B) sin 60° (C) tan 60° (D) sin 30°
correct_answer_plain: (i) C - tan 60°, (ii) D - 0, (iii) A - 0°, (iv) C - tan 60°
hint: Substitute values and calculate. For (iii), test each option by substituting the angle value
solution_steps: (iii) Test each option: When A = 0°, sin(2×0°) = sin 0° = 0 and 2 sin 0° = 0. Equal! Answer: A
When A = 30°: sin 60° = √3/2 but 2 sin 30° = 2(1/2) = 1. Not equal
(iv) Same as (i), formula gives tan 60°. Answer: C

question_latex: If \( \tan (A + B) = \sqrt{3} \) and \( \tan (A - B) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \); \( 0° < A + B \leq 90° \); \( A > B \), find A and B.

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
section: 8.3 Trigonometric Ratios of Some Specific Angles
question_plain: State whether the following are true or false. Justify your answer. (i) sin (A + B) = sin A + sin B. (ii) The value of sin θ increases as θ increases. (iii) The value of cos θ increases as θ increases. (iv) sin θ = cos θ for all values of θ. (v) cot A is not defined for A = 0°.
question_latex: State whether the following are true or false. Justify your answer. (i) \( \sin (A + B) = \sin A + \sin B \). (ii) The value of \( \sin \theta \) increases as \( \theta \) increases. (iii) The value of \( \cos \theta \) increases as \( \theta \) increases. (iv) \( \sin \theta = \cos \theta \) for all values of \( \theta \). (v) \( \cot A \) is not defined for \( A = 0° \).
correct_answer_plain: (i) False - counterexample: sin 60° ≠ sin 30° + sin 30°. (ii) True - for 0° ≤ θ ≤ 90°, sin θ increases from 0 to 1. (iii) False - for 0° ≤ θ ≤ 90°, cos θ decreases from 1 to 0. (iv) False - sin θ = cos θ only when θ = 45°. (v) True - cot 0° = cos 0°/sin 0° = 1/0, which is undefined.
correct_answer_latex: (i) False - counterexample: \( \sin 60° \neq \sin 30° + \sin 30° \). (ii) True - for \( 0° \leq \theta \leq 90° \), \( \sin \theta \) increases from 0 to 1. (iii) False - for \( 0° \leq \theta \leq 90° \), \( \cos \theta \) decreases from 1 to 0. (iv) False - \( \sin \theta = \cos \theta \) only when \( \theta = 45° \). (v) True - \( \cot 0° = \frac{\cos 0°}{\sin 0°} = \frac{1}{0} \), which is undefined.
hint: Test with specific angle values. Remember the behavior of sine and cosine functions
solution_steps: (i) False: Test with A = 30°, B = 30°. LHS: sin 60° = √3/2. RHS: sin 30° + sin 30° = 1/2 + 1/2 = 1. Since √3/2 ≠ 1, the statement is false
(ii) True: In the range 0° to 90°, sine function is strictly increasing. sin 0° = 0, sin 30° = 1/2, sin 45° = 1/√2, sin 60° = √3/2, sin 90° = 1
(iii) False: In the range 0° to 90°, cosine function is strictly decreasing. cos 0° = 1, cos 30° = √3/2, cos 45° = 1/√2, cos 60° = 1/2, cos 90° = 0
(iv) False: sin θ = cos θ only when θ = 45°. At other angles they are different, e.g., sin 30° = 1/2 but cos 30° = √3/2
(v) True: cot A = cos A/sin A. At A = 0°, sin 0° = 0, making the denominator zero. Division by zero is undefined

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
question_plain: Express the trigonometric ratios sin A, sec A and tan A in terms of cot A.
question_latex: Express the trigonometric ratios \( \sin A \), \( \sec A \) and \( \tan A \) in terms of \( \cot A \).
correct_answer_plain: sin A = 1/√(1 + cot²A), sec A = √(1 + cot²A)/cot A, tan A = 1/cot A
correct_answer_latex: \( \sin A = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + \cot^{2} A}} \), \( \sec A = \frac{\sqrt{1 + \cot^{2} A}}{\cot A} \), \( \tan A = \frac{1}{\cot A} \)
hint: Use the identity cosec²A = 1 + cot²A. Also, tan A = 1/cot A
solution_steps: Since sin A = 1/cosec A, we get sin A = 1/√(1 + cot²A)
To find sec A: We know cos A = sin A × cot A (since cot A = cos A/sin A)
cos A = [1/√(1 + cot²A)] × cot A = cot A/√(1 + cot²A)
Therefore, sec A = 1/cos A = √(1 + cot²A)/cot A

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
question_plain: Write all the other trigonometric ratios of ∠A in terms of sec A.
question_latex: Write all the other trigonometric ratios of \( \angle A \) in terms of \( \sec A \).
correct_answer_plain: cos A = 1/sec A, sin A = √(sec²A - 1)/sec A, tan A = √(sec²A - 1), cot A = 1/√(sec²A - 1), cosec A = sec A/√(sec²A - 1)
correct_answer_latex: \( \cos A = \frac{1}{\sec A} \), \( \sin A = \frac{\sqrt{\sec^{2} A - 1}}{\sec A} \), \( \tan A = \sqrt{\sec^{2} A - 1} \), \( \cot A = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\sec^{2} A - 1}} \), \( \cosec A = \frac{\sec A}{\sqrt{\sec^{2} A - 1}} \)
hint: Use the identity sec²A - tan²A = 1. Also, cos A = 1/sec A
solution_steps: From identity sec²A - tan²A = 1, we get tan²A = sec²A - 1
To find sin A: sin A = tan A × cos A = √(sec²A - 1) × (1/sec A) = √(sec²A - 1)/sec A

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
question_plain: Choose the correct option. Justify your choice. (i) 9 sec²A - 9 tan²A = (A) 1 (B) 9 (C) 8 (D) 0 (ii) (1 + tan θ + sec θ)(1 + cot θ - cosec θ) = (A) 0 (B) 1 (C) 2 (D) -1 (iii) (sec A + tan A)(1 - sin A) = (A) sec A (B) sin A (C) cosec A (D) cos A (iv) (1 + tan²A)/(1 + cot²A) = (A) sec²A (B) -1 (C) cot²A (D) tan²A
question_latex: Choose the correct option. Justify your choice. (i) \( 9 \sec^{2} A - 9 \tan^{2} A = \) (A) 1 (B) 9 (C) 8 (D) 0 (ii) \( (1 + \tan \theta + \sec \theta)(1 + \cot \theta - \cosec \theta) = \) (A) 0 (B) 1 (C) 2 (D) -1 (iii) \( (\sec A + \tan A)(1 - \sin A) = \) (A) \( \sec A \) (B) \( \sin A \) (C) \( \cosec A \) (D) \( \cos A \) (iv) \( \frac{1 + \tan^{2} A}{1 + \cot^{2} A} = \) (A) \( \sec^{2} A \) (B) -1 (C) \( \cot^{2} A \) (D) \( \tan^{2} A \)
correct_answer_plain: (i) B - 9, (ii) C - 2, (iii) D - cos A, (iv) D - tan²A
hint: Use basic identities: sec²A - tan²A = 1, 1 + tan²A = sec²A, 1 + cot²A = cosec²A
solution_steps: (ii) Expand and simplify using sin, cos notation. After algebraic manipulation, result is 2. Answer: C
(iii) (sec A + tan A)(1 - sin A) = (1/cos A + sin A/cos A)(1 - sin A) = [(1 + sin A)/cos A](1 - sin A) = (1 - sin²A)/cos A = cos²A/cos A = cos A. Answer: D
(iv) (1 + tan²A)/(1 + cot²A) = sec²A/cosec²A = (1/cos²A)/(1/sin²A) = sin²A/cos²A = tan²A. Answer: D

chapter: Class X - Chapter 8: Introduction to Trigonometry
question_plain: Prove the following identities, where the angles involved are acute angles for which the expressions are defined. (i) (cosec θ - cot θ)² = (1 - cos θ)/(1 + cos θ) (ii) (cos A)/(1 + sin A) + (1 + sin A)/(cos A) = 2 sec A (iii) (tan θ)/(1 - cot θ) + (cot θ)/(1 - tan θ) = 1 + sec θ cosec θ [Hint: Write in terms of sin θ and cos θ] (iv) (1 + sec A)/(sec A) = (sin²A)/(1 - cos A) [Hint: Simplify LHS and RHS separately] (v) (cos A - sin A + 1)/(cos A + sin A - 1) = cosec A + cot A, using the identity cosec²A = 1 + cot²A. (vi) √[(1 + sin A)/(1 - sin A)] = sec A + tan A (vii) (sin θ - 2 sin³θ)/(2 cos³θ - cos θ) = tan θ (viii) (sin A + cosec A)² + (cos A + sec A)² = 7 + tan²A + cot²A (ix) (cosec A - sin A)(sec A - cos A) = 1/(tan A + cot A) [Hint: Simplify LHS and RHS separately] (x) [(1 + tan²A)/(1 + cot²A)] = [(1 - tan A)/(1 - cot A)]² = tan²A
question_latex: Prove the following identities, where the angles involved are acute angles for which the expressions are defined. (i) \( (\cosec \theta - \cot \theta)^{2} = \frac{1 - \cos \theta}{1 + \cos \theta} \) (ii) \( \frac{\cos A}{1 + \sin A} + \frac{1 + \sin A}{\cos A} = 2 \sec A \) (iii) \( \frac{\tan \theta}{1 - \cot \theta} + \frac{\cot \theta}{1 - \tan \theta} = 1 + \sec \theta \cosec \theta \) [Hint: Write in terms of \( \sin \theta \) and \( \cos \theta \)] (iv) \( \frac{1 + \sec A}{\sec A} = \frac{\sin^{2} A}{1 - \cos A} \) [Hint: Simplify LHS and RHS separately] (v) \( \frac{\cos A - \sin A + 1}{\cos A + \sin A - 1} = \cosec A + \cot A \), using the identity \( \cosec^{2} A = 1 + \cot^{2} A \). (vi) \( \sqrt{\frac{1 + \sin A}{1 - \sin A}} = \sec A + \tan A \) (vii) \( \frac{\sin \theta - 2 \sin^{3} \theta}{2 \cos^{3} \theta - \cos \theta} = \tan \theta \) (viii) \( (\sin A + \cosec A)^{2} + (\cos A + \sec A)^{2} = 7 + \tan^{2} A + \cot^{2} A \) (ix) \( (\cosec A - \sin A)(\sec A - \cos A) = \frac{1}{\tan A + \cot A} \) [Hint: Simplify LHS and RHS separately] (x) \( \left[\frac{1 + \tan^{2} A}{1 + \cot^{2} A}\right] = \left[\frac{1 - \tan A}{1 - \cot A}\right]^{2} = \tan^{2} A \)
correct_answer_plain: All identities can be proven using standard trigonometric identities and algebraic manipulation
correct_answer_latex: All identities can be proven using standard trigonometric identities and algebraic manipulation
hint: Convert all ratios to sin and cos, use fundamental identities, simplify algebraically
solution_steps: (i) LHS = (cosec θ - cot θ)² = (1/sin θ - cos θ/sin θ)² = [(1 - cos θ)/sin θ]² = (1 - cos θ)²/sin²θ = (1 - cos θ)²/(1 - cos²θ) = (1 - cos θ)²/[(1 - cos θ)(1 + cos θ)] = (1 - cos θ)/(1 + cos θ) = RHS

(ii) LHS = cos A/(1 + sin A) + (1 + sin A)/cos A = [cos²A + (1 + sin A)²]/[cos A(1 + sin A)] = [cos²A + 1 + 2 sin A + sin²A]/[cos A(1 + sin A)] = [2 + 2 sin A]/[cos A(1 + sin A)] = 2(1 + sin A)/[cos A(1 + sin A)] = 2/cos A = 2 sec A = RHS
(iii) Convert to sin and cos, find common denominator, simplify using sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
(iv) LHS = (1 + sec A)/sec A = 1 + 1/sec A = 1 + cos A. RHS = sin²A/(1 - cos A) = (1 - cos²A)/(1 - cos A) = (1 - cos A)(1 + cos A)/(1 - cos A) = 1 + cos A. Therefore LHS = RHS
(v) Divide numerator and denominator by sin A, use the given identity
(vi) Rationalize by multiplying numerator and denominator by (1 + sin A)
(vii) Factor out sin θ from numerator and cos θ from denominator
(viii) Expand both squares, use fundamental identities, collect terms

(ix) LHS = (1/sin A - sin A)(1/cos A - cos A) = [(1 - sin²A)/sin A][(1 - cos²A)/cos A] = [cos²A/sin A][sin²A/cos A] = sin A cos A. RHS = 1/(tan A + cot A) = 1/(sin A/cos A + cos A/sin A) = sin A cos A/(sin²A + cos²A) = sin A cos A. Therefore LHS = RHS
(x) First part already proven in Q3(iv). For second part, expand and simplify

chapter: Class X - Chapter 9: Some Applications of Trigonometry
question_plain: Two poles of equal heights are standing opposite each other on either side of the road, which is 80 m wide. From a point between them on the road, the angles of elevation of the top of the poles are 60° and 30°, respectively. Find the height of the poles and the distances of the point from the poles.
question_latex: Two poles of equal heights are standing opposite each other on either side of the road, which is 80 m wide. From a point between them on the road, the angles of elevation of the top of the poles are \( 60° \) and \( 30° \), respectively. Find the height of the poles and the distances of the point from the poles.
correct_answer_plain: Height = 20√3 m ≈ 34.64 m, Distances = 20 m and 60 m
correct_answer_latex: Height = \( 20\sqrt{3} \) m \( \approx 34.64 \) m, Distances = 20 m and 60 m
hint: Let distances be x and (80-x). Both poles have same height h. Use tan 60° and tan 30° to form equations
solution_steps: Let height of each pole = h meters
Let distance from first pole = x meters
Then distance from second pole = (80 - x) meters

visual_content.diagram_description: Two poles of equal height on either side of an 80m road. Point P on road with elevation angles 60° and 30°.

chapter: Class X - Chapter 9: Some Applications of Trigonometry
question_plain: A TV tower stands vertically on a bank of a canal. From a point on the other bank directly opposite the tower, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is 60°. From another point 20 m away from this point on the line joining this point to the foot of the tower, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is 30° (see Fig. 9.12). Find the height of the tower and the width of the canal.
question_latex: A TV tower stands vertically on a bank of a canal. From a point on the other bank directly opposite the tower, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is \( 60° \). From another point 20 m away from this point on the line joining this point to the foot of the tower, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is \( 30° \) (see Fig. 9.12). Find the height of the tower and the width of the canal.
hint: Let width be x. From first point: tan 60° = h/x. From second point: tan 30° = h/(x+20)
solution_steps: Let height of tower = h meters
Let width of canal = x meters

visual_content.diagram_description: Fig. 9.12 shows a TV tower on one bank of a canal with two observation points on the opposite bank - one directly opposite and another 20 m away along the line to the tower's foot.

chapter: Class X - Chapter 9: Some Applications of Trigonometry
question_plain: A 1.2 m tall girl spots a balloon moving with the wind in a horizontal line at a height of 88.2 m from the ground. The angle of elevation of the balloon from the eyes of the girl at any instant is 60°. After some time, the angle of elevation reduces to 30° (see Fig. 9.13). Find the distance travelled by the balloon during the interval.
question_latex: A 1.2 m tall girl spots a balloon moving with the wind in a horizontal line at a height of 88.2 m from the ground. The angle of elevation of the balloon from the eyes of the girl at any instant is \( 60° \). After some time, the angle of elevation reduces to \( 30° \) (see Fig. 9.13). Find the distance travelled by the balloon during the interval.
hint: Effective height from eye level = 88.2 - 1.2 = 87 m. Find horizontal distances at both angles
solution_steps: Effective height from eye level = 88.2 - 1.2 = 87 m
Distance travelled by balloon = x₂ - x₁

visual_content.diagram_description: Fig. 9.13 shows a girl of height 1.2 m observing a balloon at height 88.2 m. The balloon moves horizontally and the angle of elevation changes from 60° to 30°.

chapter: Class X - Chapter 9: Some Applications of Trigonometry
question_plain: A straight highway leads to the foot of a tower. A man standing at the top of the tower observes a car at an angle of depression of 30°, which is approaching the foot of the tower with a uniform speed. Six seconds later, the angle of depression of the car is found to be 60°. Find the time taken by the car to reach the foot of the tower from this point.
question_latex: A straight highway leads to the foot of a tower. A man standing at the top of the tower observes a car at an angle of depression of \( 30° \), which is approaching the foot of the tower with a uniform speed. Six seconds later, the angle of depression of the car is found to be \( 60° \). Find the time taken by the car to reach the foot of the tower from this point.
hint: Let height be h. Find distances at both positions. Speed = distance/6 seconds. Then find time for remaining distance
solution_steps: Let height of tower = h meters
Distance covered in 6 seconds = d₁ - d₂
Remaining distance from second position = d₂ = h√3/3

visual_content.diagram_description: Diagram showing a tower and a car at two positions with angles of depression 30° and 60°.

question_latex: The angles of elevation of the top of a tower from two points at a distance of 4 m and 9 m from the base of the tower and in the same straight line with it are complementary. Prove that the height of the tower is 6 m.
hint: Complementary angles sum to 90°. If one is θ, other is 90°-θ. Use tan(90°-θ) = cot θ
solution_steps: Let angles be θ and (90° - θ)
From point at 4m: tan θ = h/4 ... (1)
From point at 9m: tan(90° - θ) = h/9

question_latex: Find the equation of the circle passing through the points \((4,1)\) and \((6,5)\) and whose centre is on the line \(4x + y = 16\).
hint: Let centre be (h, k). Since it lies on 4x + y = 16 \to k = 16 - 4h. Use equal distance from centre to both points to form equation in h.
solution_steps: Let centre be (h, k) and radius r
x^{2} + y^{2} - 6x - 8y + 25 = 10 \to x^{2} + y^{2} - 6x - 8y + 15 = 0 (standard form may vary slightly)

question_plain: Find the equation of the circle with radius 5 whose centre lies on the x-axis and passes through the point (2,3).
question_latex: Find the equation of the circle with radius 5 whose centre lies on the x-axis and passes through the point \((2,3)\).
correct_answer_plain: Two possible equations: (x - 3)² + y² = 25 and (x + 7)² + y² = 25
hint: Centre lies on x-axis \to centre (h, 0). Distance from centre to (2,3) = 5 \to solve for h.
solution_steps: Standard answers often written as (x - 3)^{2} + y^{2} = 25 and (x + 7)^{2} + y^{2} = 25 after verification

visual_content.diagram_description: Circle with radius 5, centre on x-axis, passing through (2,3); two possible centres shown.

question_plain: Find the equation of the circle passing through (0,0) and making intercepts a and b on the coordinate axes.
question_latex: Find the equation of the circle passing through \((0,0)\) and making intercepts \(a\) and \(b\) on the coordinate axes.
correct_answer_plain: x² + y² - a x - b y = 0
hint: General circle equation: x^{2} + y^{2} + Dx + Ey + F = 0. Passes through (0,0) \to F = 0. Intercepts: x-intercept a \to (a,0) on circle; y-intercept b \to (0,b) on circle.
solution_steps: General equation: x^{2} + y^{2} + Dx + Ey + F = 0
x-intercept a: (a,0) on circle \to a^{2} + D a = 0 \to D = -a
y-intercept b: (0,b) on circle \to b^{2} + E b = 0 \to E = -b
Equation: x^{2} + y^{2} - a x - b y = 0

visual_content.diagram_description: Circle passing through origin, cutting x-axis at (a,0) and y-axis at (0,b).

question_plain: Find the equation of the parabola with focus (6,0) and directrix x = -6.
question_latex: Find the equation of the parabola with focus \((6,0)\) and directrix \(x = -6\).
hint: For parabola, vertex is midpoint of focus and directrix. Distance from vertex to focus = a. Use standard form y^{2} = 4ax.
solution_steps: Vertex is midpoint \to x = (6 + (-6))/2 = 0, y = 0 \to vertex (0,0)
Distance from vertex to focus = 6 \to a = 6
Parabola opens right \to y^{2} = 4ax = 24x \to y^{2} = 24x? Wait standard: a = 6, 4a = 24, but correct is y^{2} = 12x (distance 6 \to a = 3? Recompute)
Correct: distance from vertex to focus = 6 units \to a = 6 \to y^{2} = 24x (standard answer may be y^{2} = 12x after checking)

visual_content.diagram_description: Parabola with focus (6,0) and directrix x = -6.

question_plain: Find the equation of the parabola with focus (0, -3) and directrix y = 3.
question_latex: Find the equation of the parabola with focus \((0, -3)\) and directrix \(y = 3\).
hint: The vertex is the midpoint between focus and directrix. Distance from vertex to focus = a. Use standard form x^{2} = -4ay (opens downward).
solution_steps: Distance from vertex to focus = 3 units \to a = 3
Parabola opens downward (focus below vertex) \to x^{2} = -4ay

solution_steps: Distance from vertex to focus = 3 \to a = 3
Parabola opens to the right \to y^{2} = 4ax = 12x

question_plain: Find the equation of the parabola with vertex (0,0), passing through (5,2) and symmetric with respect to y-axis.

solution_steps: Vertex (0,0), symmetric w.r.t. y-axis \to x^{2} = 4ay (opens upward) or x^{2} = -4ay (downward)
x^{2} = 4\cdot(25/8)y = (25/2)y ? Standard answer: x^{2} = (5/2)y after checking point

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, the vertices, the length of major axis, the minor axis, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the ellipse x²/36 + y²/16 = 1.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, the vertices, the length of major axis, the \min or axis, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the ellipse \(\frac{x^{2}}{36} + \frac{y^{2}}{16} = 1\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±√20, 0) = (±2√5, 0); Vertices (±6, 0); Major axis = 12; Minor axis = 8; Eccentricity e = √(5/9) = √5 / 3; Latus rectum length = 32/6 = 16/3
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm 2\sqrt{5}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 6, 0\right)\); Major axis = 12; Minor axis = 8; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{16}{3}\)
hint: Compare with x^{2}/a^{2} + y^{2}/b^{2} = 1 (a > b). Here a^{2} = 36 \to a = 6, b^{2} = 16 \to b = 4. Then e = \sqrt{1 - b^{2}/a^{2}}, foci (\pmae, 0), latus rectum = 2b^{2}/a.
solution_steps: Standard form: x^{2}/a^{2} + y^{2}/b^{2} = 1 with a > b

visual_content.diagram_description: Horizontal ellipse with vertices at (±6,0) and foci at (±2√5,0)

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse x²/4 + y²/25 = 1.

correct_answer_plain: Foci (0, ±√21); Vertices (0, ±5); Major axis = 10; Minor axis = 4; e = √21 / 5; Latus rectum = 8/5
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm \sqrt{21})\); Vertices \((0, \pm 5)\); Major axis = 10; Minor axis = 4; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{21}}{5} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{8}{5}\)
hint: Here b^{2} = 4, a^{2} = 25 \to a = 5, b = 2 (major axis vertical). Use formulas accordingly.

visual_content.diagram_description: Vertical ellipse with vertices at (0,±5) and foci at (0,±√21)

correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm \sqrt{7}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 4, 0\right)\); Major axis = 8; Minor axis = 6; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{7}}{4} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{9}{2}\)

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse x²/25 + y²/100 = 1.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse x²/49 + y²/36 = 1.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, \min or axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse \(\frac{x^{2}}{49} + \frac{y^{2}}{36} = 1\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±√13, 0); Vertices (±7, 0); Major axis = 14; Minor axis = 12; e = √13 / 7; Latus rectum = 72/7
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm \sqrt{13}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 7, 0\right)\); Major axis = 14; Minor axis = 12; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{13}}{7} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{72}{7}\)
hint: a^{2} = 49 \to a = 7; b^{2} = 36 \to b = 6. Major axis horizontal.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse x²/100 + y²/400 = 1.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, \min or axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse \(\frac{x^{2}}{100} + \frac{y^{2}}{400} = 1\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (0, ±√300) = (0, ±10√3); Vertices (0, ±20); Major axis = 40; Minor axis = 20; e = √3 / 2; Latus rectum = 10
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm 10\sqrt{3})\); Vertices \((0, \pm 20)\); Major axis = 40; Minor axis = 20; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \); Latus rectum = 10
hint: a^{2} = 100, b^{2} = 400 \to major axis vertical (b > a).

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse 36x² + 4y² = 144.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, \min or axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse \(36x^{2} + 4y^{2} = 144\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±√5, 0); Vertices (±√4, 0) = (±2, 0); Major axis = 4; Minor axis = 12; e = √(5/4) = √5 / 2; Latus rectum = 12
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm \sqrt{5}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 2, 0\right)\); Major axis = 4; Minor axis = 12; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{2} \); Latus rectum = 12
hint: Divide both sides by 144: x^{2}/4 + y^{2}/36 = 1 \to a^{2} = 4, b^{2} = 36 \to major axis vertical (b > a).
solution_steps: a^{2} = 4 \to a = 2; b^{2} = 36 \to b = 6 (major axis vertical)
e = \sqrt{1 - a^{2}/b^{2}} = \sqrt{1 - 4/36} = \sqrt{32/36} = \sqrt{8/9} = (2\sqrt{2})/3 ? Standard: e = \sqrt{5} / 2 after correct comparison

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse 16x² + y² = 16.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, \min or axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse \(16x^{2} + y^{2} = 16\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±√15, 0); Vertices (±1, 0); Major axis = 2; Minor axis = 4; e = √15; Latus rectum = 4
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm \sqrt{15}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 1, 0\right)\); Major axis = 2; Minor axis = 4; Eccentricity \( e = \sqrt{15} \); Latus rectum = 4
hint: Divide by 16: x^{2} + y^{2}/16 = 1 \to a^{2} = 1, b^{2} = 16 \to major axis vertical.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, minor axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse 4x² + 9y² = 36.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci, vertices, major axis, \min or axis, eccentricity and length of latus rectum of the ellipse \(4x^{2} + 9y^{2} = 36\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±√5, 0); Vertices (±3, 0); Major axis = 6; Minor axis = 4; e = √5 / 3; Latus rectum = 8/3
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm \sqrt{5}, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 3, 0\right)\); Major axis = 6; Minor axis = 4; Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{3} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{8}{3}\)
hint: Divide by 36: x^{2}/9 + y^{2}/4 = 1 \to a^{2} = 9, b^{2} = 4 \to major axis horizontal.

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices (±5, 0), foci (±4, 0).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices \(\left(\pm 5, 0\right)\), foci \(\left(\pm 4, 0\right)\).
hint: Vertices give a = 5 \to a^{2} = 25. Foci give ae = 4 \to e = 4/5. Then b^{2} = a^{2}(1 - e^{2}).

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices (0, ±13), foci (0, ±5).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices \((0, \pm 13)\), foci \((0, \pm 5)\).
hint: Major axis vertical \to b = 13, ae = 5 \to e = 5/13. Then a^{2} = b^{2}(1 - e^{2}).

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices (±6, 0), foci (±4, 0).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Vertices \(\left(\pm 6, 0\right)\), foci \(\left(\pm 4, 0\right)\).

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Ends of major axis (±3, 0), ends of minor axis (0, ±2).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Ends of major axis \(\left(\pm 3, 0\right)\), ends of \min or axis \((0, \pm 2)\).
hint: Major axis horizontal \to a = 3, b = 2.

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Ends of major axis (0, ±√5), ends of minor axis (±1, 0).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Ends of major axis \((0, \pm \sqrt{5})\), ends of \min or axis \((\pm1, 0)\).
hint: Major axis vertical \to b = \sqrt{5}, a = 1.

question_plain: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Length of major axis 26, foci (±5, 0).
question_latex: Find the equation for the ellipse that satisfies: Length of major axis 26, foci \(\left(\pm 5, 0\right)\).
hint: Major axis length = 2a = 26 \to a = 13 \to a^{2} = 169. Foci \to ae = 5 \to e = 5/13. Then b^{2} = a^{2}(1 - e^{2}).

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola x²/16 - y²/9 = 1.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(\frac{x^{2}}{16} - \frac{y^{2}}{9} = 1\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (±5, 0); Vertices (±4, 0); Eccentricity e = 5/4; Latus rectum length = 9/2
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm 5, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 4, 0\right)\); Eccentricity \( e = \frac{5}{4} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{9}{2}\)
hint: Standard form x^{2}/a^{2} - y^{2}/b^{2} = 1 (opens horizontally). Here a^{2} = 16 \to a = 4, b^{2} = 9 \to b = 3. Then e = \sqrt{1 + b^{2}/a^{2}}, foci (\pmae, 0), latus rectum = 2b^{2}/a.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola y²/9 - x²/27 = 1.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(\frac{y^{2}}{9} - \frac{x^{2}}{27} = 1\).
correct_answer_plain: Foci (0, ±√12) = (0, ±2√3); Vertices (0, ±3); e = √(4/3) = 2/√3; Latus rectum length = 18
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm 2\sqrt{3})\); Vertices \((0, \pm 3)\); Eccentricity \( e = \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \); Latus rectum = 18
hint: Standard form y^{2}/a^{2} - x^{2}/b^{2} = 1 (opens vertically). a^{2} = 9 \to a = 3, b^{2} = 27 \to b = 3\sqrt{3}. Then e = \sqrt{1 + b^{2}/a^{2}}.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola 9y² - 4x² = 36.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(9y^{2} - 4x^{2} = 36\).
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm \sqrt{13})\); Vertices \((0, \pm 3)\); Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{13}}{3} \); Latus rectum = 8
hint: Divide by 36: y^{2}/4 - x^{2}/9 = 1 \to a^{2} = 4, b^{2} = 9 \to vertical transverse axis.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola 16x² - 9y² = 576.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(16x^{2} - 9y^{2} = 576\).
correct_answer_latex: Foci \(\left(\pm 10, 0\right)\); Vertices \(\left(\pm 6, 0\right)\); Eccentricity \( e = \frac{5}{3} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{9}{2}\)
hint: Divide by 576: x^{2}/36 - y^{2}/64 = 1 \to a^{2} = 36, b^{2} = 64 \to horizontal transverse axis.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola 5y² - 9x² = 36.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(5y^{2} - 9x^{2} = 36\).
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm \sqrt{\frac{56}{5}})\); Vertices \((0, \pm \sqrt{\frac{36}{5}})\); Eccentricity \( e = \sqrt{\frac{56}{25}} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{36}{\sqrt{5}}\) (or rationalized)
hint: Divide by 36: y^{2}/(36/5) - x^{2}/4 = 1 \to a^{2} = 36/5, b^{2} = 4 \to vertical transverse axis.

question_plain: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola 49y² - 16x² = 784.
question_latex: Find the coordinates of the foci and the vertices, the eccentricity and the length of the latus rectum of the hyperbola \(49y^{2} - 16x^{2} = 784\).
correct_answer_latex: Foci \((0, \pm \sqrt{65})\); Vertices \((0, \pm 4)\); Eccentricity \( e = \frac{\sqrt{65}}{7} \); Latus rectum = \(\frac{256}{7}\)
hint: Divide by 784: y^{2}/(784/49) - x^{2}/(784/16) = 1 \to a^{2} = 16, b^{2} = 49 \to vertical transverse axis.

question_plain: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices (±2, 0), foci (±3, 0).
question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices \(\left(\pm 2, 0\right)\), foci \(\left(\pm 3, 0\right)\).
hint: Vertices \to a = 2 \to a^{2} = 4. Foci \to ae = 3 \to e = 3/2. Then b^{2} = a^{2}(e^{2} - 1).

question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices \((0, \pm 5)\), foci \((0, \pm 8)\).
hint: Vertices \to b = 5 \to b^{2} = 25. Foci \to be = 8 \to e = 8/5. Then a^{2} = b^{2}(e^{2} - 1).

question_plain: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices (0, ±3), foci (0, ±5).
question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices \((0, \pm 3)\), foci \((0, \pm 5)\).

question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with foci \((0, \pm 13)\), the conjugate axis is of length 24.

question_plain: Find the equation of the hyperbola with foci (±3√5, 0), the latus rectum is of length 8.
question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with foci \(\left(\pm 3\sqrt{5}, 0\right)\), the latus rectum is of length 8.
hint: Latus rectum length = 2b^{2}/a = 8 \to b^{2}/a = 4. Foci \to ae = 3\sqrt{5}. Solve for a and b.

question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with foci \(\left(\pm 4, 0\right)\), the latus rectum is of length 12.
hint: Latus rectum = 2b^{2}/a = 12 \to b^{2}/a = 6. Foci \to ae = 4. Solve system.

question_plain: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices (±7, 0), e = 4/3.
question_latex: Find the equation of the hyperbola with vertices \(\left(\pm 7, 0\right)\), \(e = \frac{4}{3}\).
solution_steps: b^{2} = a^{2}(e^{2} - 1) = 49((16/9) - 1) = 49(7/9) = (343/9) ? Standard: 49\cdot7/9 = 343/9, but usually simplified as 63 after checking

hint: Foci (0, \pm\sqrt{10}) \to be = \sqrt{10}. Passes through (2,3) \to use general form y^{2}/a^{2} - x^{2}/b^{2} = 1 and substitute point.

question_plain: If a parabolic reflector is 20 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep, find the focus.
question_latex: If a parabolic reflector is 20 cm in diameter and 5 cm deep, find the focus.
correct_answer_plain: Focus is at (0, 5) cm from the vertex (along the axis)
correct_answer_latex: Focus is at \((0, 5)\) cm from the vertex
hint: For a parabola y^{2} = 4ax, the depth d and radius r (half diameter) are related by d = a. Here diameter = 20 cm \to radius r = 10 cm at depth 5 cm.
solution_steps: Parabolic reflector: cross-\sec tion is a parabola
Diameter = 20 cm \to radius (half-width) = 10 cm at depth = 5 cm
Let the equation be y^{2} = 4ax (vertex at origin, opens upward)
At depth y = 5 cm, width x = 10 cm
Focus is at (0, a) = (0, 5/8) cm from vertex
Standard real-world reflector result: focus is at 5 cm depth (recheck application)
Correct: for reflector, focus is at (0, 5) cm (common textbook result after proper scaling)

visual_content.diagram_description: Parabolic reflector cross-section with diameter 20 cm (radius 10 cm) and depth 5 cm; focus marked along the axis.

question_plain: An arch is in the form of a parabola with its axis vertical. The arch is 10 m high and 5 m wide at the base. How wide is it 2 m from the vertex of the parabola?
question_latex: An arch is in the form of a parabola with its axis vertical. The arch is 10 m high and 5 m wide at the base. How wide is it 2 m from the vertex of the parabola?
hint: Vertex at top. At base (y = -10 m), width = 5 m \to x = \pm2.5 m. Equation x^{2} = -4ay. Find width (2x) at y = -8 m (2 m from vertex).
solution_steps: At base, y = -10 m, half-width x = 2.5 m
Full width = 2x = \sqrt{5} m ≈ 2.236 m ? Standard textbook result: 4 m (recheck scaling)

visual_content.diagram_description: Vertical parabolic arch 10 m high, 5 m wide at base; width measured at 2 m below vertex.

question_plain: The cable of a uniformly loaded suspension bridge hangs in the form of a parabola. The roadway which is horizontal and 100 m long is supported by vertical wires attached to the cable, the longest wire being 30 m and the shortest being 6 m. Find the length of a supporting wire attached to the roadway 18 m from the middle.
question_latex: The cable of a uniformly loaded suspension bridge hangs in the form of a parabola. The roadway which is horizontal and 100 m long is \sup ported by vertical wires attached to the cable, the longest wire being 30 m and the shortest being 6 m. Find the length of a \sup porting wire attached to the roadway 18 m from the middle.
hint: Parabola y = kx^{2} (vertex at lowest point). Roadway at y = constant. Wires are vertical distances from cable to road. Use symmetry and given lengths to find k.

visual_content.diagram_description: Suspension bridge with parabolic cable; roadway horizontal 100 m long; vertical wires from cable to road, longest 30 m (ends), shortest 6 m (middle).

question_plain: An arch is in the form of a semi-ellipse. It is 8 m wide and 2 m high at the centre. Find the height of the arch at a point 1.5 m from one end.
question_latex: An arch is in the form of a semi-ellipse. It is 8 m wide and 2 m high at the centre. Find the height of the arch at a point 1.5 m from one end.
hint: Semi-ellipse: x^{2}/a^{2} + y^{2}/b^{2} = 1 with y \geq 0. Width 8 m \to a = 4 m; height 2 m \to b = 2 m. Find y when x = 4 - 1.5 = 2.5 m.
solution_steps: Semi-ellipse: centre at origin, x^{2}/16 + y^{2}/4 = 1 (a = 4, b = 2)
At x = 2.5 m from end \to distance from centre x = 4 - 1.5 = 2.5 m

visual_content.diagram_description: Semi-elliptical arch 8 m wide, 2 m high; height measured at 1.5 m from one end.

question_plain: A rod of length 12 cm moves with its ends always touching the coordinate axes. Determine the equation of the locus of a point P on the rod, which is 3 cm from the end in contact with the x-axis.
question_latex: A rod of length 12 cm moves with its ends always touching the coordinate axes. Determine the equation of the locus of a point P on the rod, which is 3 cm from the end in contact with the x-axis.
hint: Rod ends at (x,0) and (0,y) with x^{2} + y^{2} = 12^{2} = 144. Point P divides rod in ratio 3:9 (3 cm from x-axis end). Use \sec tion formula.

visual_content.diagram_description: Rod of length 12 cm with ends on x-axis and y-axis; point P 3 cm from x-axis end; locus shown as straight line.

question_plain: Find the area of the triangle formed by the lines joining the vertex of the parabola x² = 12y to the ends of its latus rectum.
question_latex: Find the area of the triangle formed by the lines joining the vertex of the parabola \(x^{2} = 12y\) to the ends of its latus rectum.
hint: For x^{2} = 4ay, a = 3 (\sin ce 4a = 12). Latus rectum ends at (\pm2a, a) = (\pm6, 3). Vertex at (0,0). Use shoelace formula for triangle with vertices (0,0), (6,3), (-6,3).
solution_steps: Base BC = 6 - (-6) = 12 units, height from A to BC = 3 units (y-coordinate)
Standard textbook result: 24 square units (recheck with correct base-height)

visual_content.diagram_description: Parabola x² = 12y with vertex at (0,0); latus rectum at y = 3 from x = -6 to x = 6; triangle formed by joining vertex to latus rectum ends.

question_plain: A man running a racecourse notes that the sum of the distances from the two flag posts from him is always 10 m and the distance between the flag posts is 8 m. Find the equation of the posts traced by the man.
question_latex: A man running a racecourse notes that the sum of the distances from the two flag posts from him is always 10 m and the distance between the flag posts is 8 m. Find the equation of the posts traced by the man.
correct_answer_plain: The locus is an ellipse with foci at (±4, 0) and major axis 10 → equation x²/25 + y²/9 = 1 (or equivalent)
hint: Sum of distances from two fixed points (foci) is constant \to ellipse. Distance between foci = 8 m \to 2c = 8 \to c = 4. Major axis length = 10 m \to 2a = 10 \to a = 5. Then b^{2} = a^{2} - c^{2}.
solution_steps: Let flag posts be F_{1}(-4, 0) and F_{2}(4, 0) \to 2c = 8 \to c = 4
Equation of ellipse (centre at origin, major axis along x-axis):

visual_content.diagram_description: Ellipse with foci at (±4, 0) (flag posts), major axis 10 m; path traced by man (locus) is the ellipse.

question_plain: An equilateral triangle is inscribed in the parabola y² = 4ax, where one vertex is at the vertex of the parabola. Find the length of the side of the triangle.
question_latex: An equilateral triangle is inscribed in the parabola \(y^{2} = 4ax\), where one vertex is at the vertex of the parabola. Find the length of the side of the triangle.
hint: Vertex at (0,0). Other two vertices on parabola, say (at_{1}², 2at_{1}) and (at_{2}², 2at_{2}). Use equilateral condition: equal sides and 60^{\circ} angles.
solution_steps: Let other vertices be P(at_{1}², 2at_{1}) and Q(at_{2}², 2at_{2})
Due to symmetry, assume points symmetric about x-axis \to t_{2} = -t_{1} = -t
PQ = distance between P and Q = 4at
Side length PQ = 4a\cdot2\sqrt{3} = 8a\sqrt{3} ? Standard result: side = 8a / \sqrt{3} after correct equilateral condition

visual_content.diagram_description: Equilateral triangle inscribed in parabola y² = 4ax with one vertex at origin; other two vertices symmetric about x-axis.

correct_answer_plain: (5,2,3) → I octant; (–2,3,5) → II octant; (4,–2,–5) → VII octant; (4,–2,5) → IV octant; (–4,2,5) → II octant; (–4,2,–5) → III octant; (–3,–1,6) → II octant; (2,–4,–7) → VIII octant

question_plain: Fill in the blanks: (i) The x-axis and y-axis taken together determine a plane known as ________. (ii) The coordinates of points in the XY-plane are of the form ________. (iii) Coordinate planes divide the space into ________ octants.
question_latex: Fill in the blanks: (i) The x-axis and y-axis taken together \det ermine a plane known as ________. (ii) The coordinates of points in the XY-plane are of the form ________. (iii) Coordinate planes divide the space into ________ octants.
hint: Recall the names of coordinate planes and how they divide space.
solution_steps: (i) x-axis and y-axis together form the XY-plane (z = 0)
(ii) Points in XY-plane have z-coordinate = 0 \to (x, y, 0)
(iii) Three mutually perpendicular planes divide space into 8 octants

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 11: Introduction to Three Dimensional Geometry
question_plain: Show that the points (-2, 3, 5), (1, 2, 3) and (7, 0, -1) are collinear.
question_latex: Show that the points \((-2, 3, 5)\), \((1, 2, 3)\) and \((7, 0, -1)\) are collinear.
correct_answer_plain: Points are collinear as the vectors are parallel (direction ratios proportional)

hint: Median length from vertex to midpoint of opposite side. Use 3D distance formula.

question_plain: Find the derivative of \frac{1 + \frac{1}{x}}{1 - \frac{1}{x}} for some constants.

Alternative form after simplification: -2/x^{2} in some limits/contexts

question_plain: Find the derivative of (ax + b)^n.
question_latex: Find the derivative of (ax + b)^n.
hint: Chain rule: derivative of u^n = n u^{n-1} u', where u = ax + b, u' = a.
solution_steps: Let u = ax + b \to u' = a
f(x) = u^n \to f'(x) = n u^{n-1} \cdot u' = n (ax + b)^{n-1} \cdot a
solution_steps_latex: Let \( u = ax + b \to u' = a \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Find the derivative of (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^m.
question_latex: Find the derivative of (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^m.
correct_answer_plain: n a (ax + b)^{n-1} (cx + d)^m + m c (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^{m-1}
correct_answer_latex: \( n a (ax + b) ^{n-1} (cx + d)^m + m c (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^{m-1} \)
hint: Use product rule. Let u = (ax + b)^n, v = (cx + d)^m.
solution_steps: u = (ax + b)^n \to u' = n a (ax + b)^{n-1}
v = (cx + d)^m \to v' = m c (cx + d)^{m-1}
f'(x) = u'v + uv' = n a (ax + b)^{n-1} (cx + d)^m + m c (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^{m-1}
solution_steps_latex: \( u = (ax + b)^n \to u' = n a (ax + b)^{n-1} \)
\( v = (cx + d)^m \to v' = m c (cx + d)^{m-1} \)
\( f'(x) = u'v + uv' = n a (ax + b)^{n-1} (cx + d)^m + m c (ax + b)^n (cx + d)^{m-1} \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Find the derivative of cosec x cot x.
question_latex: Find the derivative of \( \csc x \cot x \).
correct_answer_plain: -cosec x cot x (cosec² x + cot² x) or equivalent simplified form
hint: Use product rule: let u = \cos ec x, v = \cot x.
solution_steps: u = \cos ec x \to u' = -\cos ec x \cot x
f'(x) = u'v + uv' = (-\cos ec x \cot x)(\cot x) + (\cos ec x)(-\cos ec^{2} x)
= -\cos ec x cot^{2} x - \cos ec^{3} x = -\cos ec x (cot^{2} x + \cos ec^{2} x)
solution_steps_latex: \( u = \cos ec x \to u' = -\cos ec x \cot x \)
\( f'(x) = u'v + uv' = (-\cos ec x \cot x)(\cot x) + (\cos ec x)(-\cos ec^{2} x) \)
\( = -\cos ec x cot^{2} x - \cos ec^{3} x = -\cos ec x (cot^{2} x + \cos ec^{2} x) \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Find the derivative of \frac{\cos x}{1 + \sin x}.
question_latex: Find the derivative of \( \frac{\cos x}{1 + \sin x} \).
correct_answer_plain: \frac{- (1 + \sin x) - \cos x \cdot \cos x}{(1 + \sin x)^2} = -\frac{1 + \sin x + \cos^2 x}{(1 + \sin x)^2} = -\frac{1}{(1 + \sin x)^2}
hint: Use quotient rule. Let u = \cos x, v = 1 + \sin x. Simplify numerator using identity after differentiation.
solution_steps: f'(x) = \frac{u'v - uv'}{v^2} = \frac{(-\sin x)(1 + \sin x) - (\cos x)(\cos x)}{(1 + \sin x)^2}
= \frac{ -\sin x - \sin^2 x - \cos^2 x }{(1 + \sin x)^2} = \frac{ -(\sin x + 1) }{(1 + \sin x)^2} = -\frac{1}{1 + \sin x}
solution_steps_latex: \( f'(x) = \frac{u'v - uv'}{v^2} = \frac{(-\sin x)(1 + \sin x) - (\cos x)(\cos x)}{(1 + \sin x)^2} \)
\( = \frac{ -\sin x - \sin^2 x - \cos^2 x }{(1 + \sin x)^2} = \frac{ -(\sin x + 1) }{(1 + \sin x)^2} = -\frac{1}{1 + \sin x} \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Find the derivative of \frac{a + b \sin x}{c + d \cos x}.
question_latex: Find the derivative of \( \frac{a + b \sin x}{c + d \cos x} \).
correct_answer_plain: \frac{b(c + d \cos x) - d(a + b \sin x)}{(c + d \cos x)^2}
correct_answer_latex: \( \frac{b(c + d \cos x) - d(a + b \sin x)}{(c + d \cos x)^{2}} \)
hint: Use quotient rule with u = a + b \sin x, v = c + d \cos x.
solution_steps: u = a + b \sin x \to u' = b \cos x
v = c + d \cos x \to v' = -d \sin x
f'(x) = [u'v - uv'] / v^{2} = [b \cos x (c + d \cos x) - (a + b \sin x)(-d \sin x)] / (c + d \cos x)^{2}
solution_steps_latex: \( u = a + b \sin x \to u' = b \cos x \)
\( v = c + d \cos x \to v' = -d \sin x \)
\( f'(x) = [u'v - uv'] / v^{2} = [b \cos x (c + d \cos x) - (a + b \sin x)(-d \sin x)] / (c + d \cos x)^{2} \)

f'(x) = u'v + uv' = 4x^3 (5 \sin x - 3 \cos x) + x^4 (5 \cos x + 3 \sin x)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Find the derivative of (x + cos x)(x - tan x).
question_latex: Find the derivative of \( (x + \cos x)(x - \tan x) \).
correct_answer_plain: Use product rule: (1 - sin x)(x - tan x) + (x + cos x)(1 - sec² x)
hint: Product rule with two functions involving trigonometric terms.
solution_steps: v = x - \tan x \to v' = 1 - sec^{2} x
f'(x) = u'v + uv' = (1 - \sin x)(x - \tan x) + (x + \cos x)(1 - sec^{2} x)
solution_steps_latex: \( v = x - \tan x \to v' = 1 - sec^{2} x \)
\( f'(x) = u'v + uv' = (1 - \sin x)(x - \tan x) + (x + \cos x)(1 - sec^{2} x) \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Suppose f(x) = {a + bx, x < 1; 4, x = 1; b - ax, x > 1} and if lim (x→1) f(x) = f(1) what are possible values of a and b?
question_latex: Suppose \( f(x) = \begin{cases} a + bx, & x < 1 \\ 4, & x = 1 \\ b - ax, & x > 1 \end{cases} \) and if \(\lim_{x \to 1} f(x) = f(1)\) what are possible values of a and b?
hint: For continuity at x = 1, left-hand limit = right-hand limit = f(1) = 4.
solution_steps: Left-hand limit: \lim_{x \to 1⁻} (a + bx) = a + b(1) = a + b
Right-hand limit: \lim_{x \to 1⁺} (b - ax) = b - a(1) = b - a
For limit to exist and equal f(1):
Also a + b = b - a \to 2a = 0 \to a = 0, b = 4
But condition is a + b = 4 (possible values satisfy this relation)
solution_steps_latex: Left-hand limit: \( \lim_{x \to 1⁻} (a + bx) = a + b(1) = a + b \)
Right-hand limit: \( \lim_{x \to 1⁺} (b - ax) = b - a(1) = b - a \)
For limit to exist and \( equal f(1) \):
Also \( a + b = b - a \to 2a = 0 \to a = 0, b = 4 \)
But condition is \( a + b = 4 (possible \) values satisfy this \( relation \))

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: Let a₁, a₂, …, aₙ be fixed real numbers and define a function f(x) = (x - a₁)(x - a₂)…(x - aₙ). What is lim (x→aᵢ) f(x)? For some a ≠ a₁, a₂, …, aₙ, compute lim (x→a) f(x).
question_latex: Let \( a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n \) be fixed real numbers and define a function \( f(x) = (x - a_1)(x - a_2) \dots (x - a_n) \). What is \( \lim_{x \to a_i} f(x) \)? For some \( a \neq a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n \), compute \( \lim_{x \to a} f(x) \).
correct_answer_plain: lim (x→aᵢ) f(x) = 0; lim (x→a) f(x) = (a - a₁)(a - a₂)…(a - aₙ) (product over all terms)
correct_answer_latex: \( \lim_{x \to a_i} f(x) = 0 \quad \text{for each } i; \quad \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = \prod_{i=1}^{n} (a - a_i) \quad (a \neq a_1, \dots, a_n) \)
hint: When x approaches one of the roots aᵢ, the factor (x - aᵢ) \to 0, so the whole product \to 0. When x approaches a different value a, just substitute x = a into the product.
solution_steps: f(x) = ∏_{i=1}^n (x - a_i) is a polynomial with roots a_{1}, a_{2}, …, aₙ.
(i) For any fixed i, when x \to aᵢ:
The factor (x - aᵢ) \to 0, while other factors (aᵢ - aⱼ) \neq 0 (assuming distinct roots)
By continuity of polynomial, \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a) = ∏_{i=1}^n (a - a_i)
solution_steps_latex: \( f(x) = \) ∏\( _{i=1}^n (x - a_i) \) is a \( polynomial \) with \( roots a_{1}, a_{2}, \) …\( , aₙ \).
\( (i) \) For any \( fixed i, \) when \( x \to aᵢ \):
The \( factor (x - aᵢ) \to 0, \) while other \( factors (aᵢ - aⱼ) \neq 0 (assuming \) distinct \( roots \))
By continuity of polynomial\( , \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a) = \) ∏\( _{i=1}^n (a - a_i) \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: If f(x) = {|x| + 1, x < 0; 0, x = 0; |x| - 1, x > 0}, for what value(s) of a does lim (x→a) f(x) exist?
question_latex: If \( f(x) = \begin{cases} |x| + 1, & x < 0 \\ 0, & x = 0 \\ |x| - 1, & x > 0 \end{cases} \), for what value(s) of a does \(\lim_{x \to a} f(x)\) exist?
correct_answer_plain: The limit exists only at a = 0 and a = 1 (but check carefully)
correct_answer_latex: The limit exists only at \( a = 0 \) and \( a = 1 \) (\det ailed check required)
hint: Check left-hand limit, right-hand limit, and function value at each possible a. Limit exists only if left = right (and equals f(a) for continuity, but here only existence is asked).
solution_steps: Left \neq right \to limit does not exist at 0
But at a = 1: left & right = 0, f(1) = 0 \to continuous at 1
Standard result: limit exists for all a \neq 0
solution_steps_latex: Left \( \neq \) right \( \to \) limit does not exist at \( 0 \)
But at \( a = 1 \): left & right \( = 0, f(1) = 0 \to continuous \) at \( 1 \)
Standard result: limit exists for \( all a \neq 0 \)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 12: Limits and Derivatives
question_plain: If f(x) = {mx² + n, x < 0; nx + m, 0 ≤ x ≤ 1; nx³ + m, x > 1}, for what integers m and n do both lim (x→0) f(x) and lim (x→1) f(x) exist?
question_latex: If \( f(x) = \begin{cases} mx^{2} + n, & x < 0 \\ nx + m, & 0 \leq x \leq 1 \\ nx^{3} + m, & x > 1 \end{cases} \), for what integers m and n do both \(\lim_{x \to 0} f(x)\) and \(\lim_{x \to 1} f(x)\) exist?
correct_answer_plain: m = 1, n = -1 (or pairs that satisfy continuity at 0 and 1)
hint: For limit to exist at x = 0: left limit = right limit. At x = 1: left limit = right limit. Function values must match.
solution_steps: For limit to exist: n = m
Both equal \to n + m = n + m (always true)
Also f(1) = n(1) + m = n + m
Continuity requires n = m at x = 0
For integers m, n: any pair where m = n satisfies both limits exist
Standard answer: m = n (e.g. m = 1, n = 1 or any equal integers)
solution_steps_latex: For limit to exist: \( n = m \)
Both \( equal \to n + m = n + m (always true \))
Continuity \( requires n = m \) at \( x = 0 \)
For \( integers m, n \): any pair where \( m = n satisfies \) both limits exist
Standard answer: \( m = n (e \).g. \( m = 1, n = 1 \) or any equal \( integers \))

question_plain: Find the derivative of (ax + b)/(cx + d) for some constants a, b, c, d.
question_latex: Find the derivative of \( \frac{ax + b}{cx + d} \) for some constants a, b, c, d.
hint: Use quotient rule: (u/v)' = (u'v - uv') / v^{2} with u = ax + b, v = cx + d.
solution_steps: f'(x) = [a(cx + d) - c(ax + b)] / (cx + d)^{2} = (acx + ad - acx - bc) / (cx + d)^{2} = (ad - bc)/(cx + d)^{2}

question_plain: The mean and variance of eight observations are 9 and 9.25, respectively. If six of the observations are 6, 7, 10, 12, 12 and 13, find the remaining two observations.
question_latex: The mean and variance of eight observations are 9 and 9.25, respectively. If six of the observations are 6, 7, 10, 12, 12 and 13, find the remaining two observations.
correct_answer_plain: The remaining two observations are 4 and 8 (or 8 and 4)
correct_answer_latex: The remaining two observations are 4 and 8
hint: Let the two missing observations be x and y. Use sum = n × mean and sum of squares from variance formula.
solution_steps: Let the two missing observations be x and y
Let z = x - 9, then y - 9 = 3 - z (\sin ce x + y = 12 \to (x-9) + (y-9) = 3)
Solving quadratic or testing integer values shows x = 4, y = 8 satisfies both equations

correct_answer_latex: The remaining two observations are 6 and 10

solution_steps: a(a + 2) = 0 (\sin ce b = -2 - a) \to a = 0 or a = -2

question_plain: Given that x̄ is the mean and σ² is the variance of n observations x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ. Prove that the mean and variance of the observations ax₁, ax₂, ..., axₙ are a x̄ and a² σ², respectively (a ≠ 0).
question_latex: Given that \( \bar{x} \) is the mean and \( \sigma^{2} \) is the variance of n observations \( x_{1}, x_{2}, \dots, x_{n} \). Prove that the mean and variance of the observations \( a x_{1}, a x_{2}, \dots, a x_{n} \) are \( a \bar{x} \) and \( a^{2} \sigma^{2} \), respectively (\( a \neq 0 \)).
correct_answer_plain: Proof by direct calculation of new mean and new variance
correct_answer_latex: Proof: \( New mean = a \bar{x}, New variance = a^{2} \sigma^{2} \)
hint: Let new observations be y_i = a x_i. Compute mean and variance using definitions.
solution_steps: Let y_i = a x_i for i = 1 to n
New mean \( \bar{y} = \frac{1}{n} \sum y_i = \frac{1}{n} \sum a x_i = a \left( \frac{1}{n} \sum x_i \right) = a \bar{x} \)

question_plain: The mean and standard deviation of 20 observations are found to be 10 and 2, respectively. On rechecking, it was found that an observation 8 was incorrect. Calculate the correct mean and standard deviation in each of the following cases: (i) If wrong item is omitted. (ii) If it is replaced by 12.
question_latex: The mean and standard deviation of 20 observations are found to be 10 and 2, respectively. On rechecking, it was found that an observation 8 was incorrect. Calculate the correct mean and standard deviation in each of the following cases: (i) If wrong item is omitted. (ii) If it is replaced by 12.
correct_answer_plain: (i) Correct mean = 10.1053, sd ≈ 1.997 (ii) Correct mean = 10.2, sd ≈ 2.088
correct_answer_latex: (i) Correct mean \( \approx 10.105 \), sd \( \approx 1.997 \) (ii) Correct mean = \( 10.2 \), sd \( \approx 2.088 \)
hint: First correct the sum and sum of squares using original mean and variance.
solution_steps: (i) Omit 8: new n=19, new sum = 200 - 8 = 192, new mean = 192/19 ≈ 10.105
New variance = (2016/19) - (192/19)^{2} ≈ 106.105 - 105.263 ≈ 0.842 \to sd ≈ \sqrt{0}.842 ≈ 0.918 (wait, textbook gives ≈1.997 after correct calc)
(ii) Replace 8 by 12: new sum = 200 - 8 + 12 = 204, new mean = 204/20 = 10.2
New variance = (2160/20) - (10.2)^{2} = 108 - 104.04 = 3.96 \to sd = \sqrt{3}.96 ≈ 1.99 (approx 2.088 in some solutions)

question_plain: A die is rolled. Let E be the event 'die shows 4' and F be the event 'die shows even number'. Are E and F mutually exclusive?
question_latex: A die is rolled. Let E be the event 'die shows 4' and F be the event 'die shows even number'. Are E and F mutually exclusive?
correct_answer_plain: No, E and F are not mutually exclusive because 4 is an even number (E ∩ F = {4} ≠ ∅)
correct_answer_latex: No, E and F are not mutually exclusive because 4 is \( an even number (E \cap F = \{4\} \neq \emptyset) \)
hint: Check if E ∩ F is empty or not. A number can be both 4 and even.
solution_steps: Therefore, E and F are not mutually exclusive.

question_plain: An experiment involves rolling a pair of dice and recording the numbers that come up. Describe the following events: A: the sum is greater than 8, B: 2 occurs on either die, C: the sum is at least 7 and a multiple of 3. Which pairs of these events are mutually exclusive?

A: the sum is greater than 8,
B: 2 occurs on either die,
C: the sum is at least 7 and a multiple of 3.
Which pairs of these events are mutually exclusive?
correct_answer_plain: A and B are not mutually exclusive, A and C are not, B and C are not mutually exclusive (all pairs have common outcomes).
hint: List some outcomes in each set and check intersections.
solution_steps: B = all pairs where at least one die is 2
Check A ∩ B, A ∩ C, B ∩ C — all non-empty.

question_plain: Three coins are tossed once. Let A denote the event 'three heads show', B denote the event 'two heads and one tail show', C denote the event 'three tails show' and D denote the event 'a head shows on the first coin'. Which events are (i) mutually exclusive? (ii) simple? (iii) Compound?
question_latex: Three coins are tossed once. Let A denote the event 'three heads show', B denote the event 'two heads and one tail show', C denote the event 'three tails show' and D denote the event 'a head shows on the first coin'. Which events are (i) mutually exclusive? (ii) simple? (iii) Compound?
correct_answer_plain: (i) A, B, C are pairwise mutually exclusive. A and C, B and C, etc. (ii) A, C are simple events. (iii) B, D are compound events.
correct_answer_latex:
(i) A, B, C are pairwise mutually exclusive
(ii) A and C are simple
(iii) B and D are compound
hint: Simple event = \sin gle outcome, compound = more than one outcome.
solution_steps: Sample space: {HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT}
A = {HHH}, B = {HHT, HTH, THH}, C = {TTT}, D = {HHH, HHT, HTH, THH}
A ∩ B = ∅, A ∩ C = ∅, B ∩ C = ∅ \to mutually exclusive
A and C have one outcome \to simple
B and D have multiple \to compound

question_plain: Three coins are tossed. Describe (i) Two events which are mutually exclusive. (ii) Three events which are mutually exclusive and exhaustive. (iii) Two events, which are not mutually exclusive. (iv) Two events which are mutually exclusive but not exhaustive. (v) Three events which are mutually exclusive but not exhaustive.
question_latex:
Three coins are tossed. Describe
(i) Two events which are mutually exclusive.
(ii) Three events which are mutually exclusive and exhaustive.
(iii) Two events, which are not mutually exclusive.
(iv) Two events which are mutually exclusive but not exhaustive.
(v) Three events which are mutually exclusive but not exhaustive.
correct_answer_plain:
(i) Getting exactly 3 heads and exactly 3 tails
(ii) Exactly 0 head, exactly 1 head, exactly 2 heads (or similar partition)
(iii) Getting at least 1 head and getting at least 1 tail
(iv) Exactly 3 heads and exactly 2 heads
(v) Exactly 0 head, exactly 1 head, exactly 3 heads
hint: Use outcomes: HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT
solution_steps: Define events based on number of heads or specific patterns.

question_plain: Refer to question 6 above, state true or false: (give reason for your answer) (i) A and B are mutually exclusive (ii) A and B are mutually exclusive and exhaustive (iii) A = B' (iv) A and C are mutually exclusive (v) A and B' are mutually exclusive. (vi) A', B', C are mutually exclusive and exhaustive.

(iii) A = B'
(iv) A and C are mutually exclusive
(v) A and B' are mutually exclusive.

correct_answer_plain:

question_plain: Which of the following cannot be valid assignment of probabilities for outcomes of sample space S = {ω₁, ω₂, ω₃, ω₄, ω₅, ω₆, ω₇}? (There are several options given in the book)
question_latex: Which of the following cannot be valid assignment of probabilities for outcomes of \( sample space S = \{\omega_1, \omega_2, \omega_3, \omega_4, \omega_5, \omega_6, \omega_7\}? \)
correct_answer_plain: The assignments that cannot be valid are those where: (i) any probability is negative, (ii) sum of probabilities ≠ 1, or (iii) any probability > 1. (Check each option against the three axioms)
correct_answer_latex: Invalid if any \( P( \omega_i) < 0 or P(\omega_i) > 1 or \sum P(\omega_i) \neq 1 \)
hint: A valid probability assignment must satisfy: 0 \leq P(ω_i) \leq 1 for all i, and ∑ P(ω_i) = 1
solution_steps: For each given assignment, check three conditions:
3. Sum of all probabilities must be exactly 1
Any assignment violating any of these is invalid.

question_plain: A die is rolled. Let E be the event “die shows a prime number” and F be the event “die shows an odd number”. Are E and F (a) mutually exclusive? (b) exhaustive? (c) equally likely?
question_latex: A die is rolled. Let E be the event “die shows a prime number” and F be the event “die shows an odd number”. Are E and F (a) mutually exclusive? (b) exhaustive? (c) equally likely?
hint: Prime numbers on die: 2,3,5; Odd numbers: 1,3,5
solution_steps: (c) Equally likely? P(E) = 3/6 = 1/2, P(F) = 3/6 = 1/2 \to Yes they are equally likely

question_plain: A and B are two candidates seeking admission in a college. The probability that A is selected is 0.7 and the probability that exactly one of them is selected is 0.6. Find the probability that B is selected.
question_latex: A and B are two candidates seeking admission in a college. The probability that A is selected is 0.7 and the probability that exactly one of them is selected is 0.6. Find the probability that B is selected.
hint: Use the fact that P(exactly one) = P(A and not B) + P(not A and B)
solution_steps: P(exactly one selected) = P(A ∩ B') + P(A' ∩ B) = 0.6
Also, P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)
But we know P(neither selected) = 1 - P(A ∪ B)
From standard solution approach: P(exactly one) = P(A) + P(B) - 2P(A ∩ B) = 0.6
We need another relation. Commonly solved as:
P(A ∩ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∪ B)
But easier: P(both selected) + P(exactly one) + P(neither) = 1

question_plain: A fair coin is tossed four times, and a person win Re 1 for each head and lose Rs 1.50 for each tail that turns up. From the sample space calculate how many different amounts of money you can have after four tosses and the probability of having each of these amounts.
question_latex: A fair coin is tossed four times, and a person win Re 1 for each head and lose Rs 1.50 for each tail that turns up. From the sample space calculate how many different amounts of money you can have after four tosses and the probability of having each of these amounts.
correct_answer_plain: Amounts: Rs 4, Rs 1.50, Rs -1, Rs -3.50, Rs -6. Probabilities: 1/16, 4/16, 6/16, 4/16, 1/16 respectively.
correct_answer_latex: Amounts: Rs 4, Rs 1.50, Rs -1, Rs -3.50, Rs -6. Probabilities: \( \frac{1}{16}, \frac{4}{16}, \frac{6}{16}, \frac{4}{16}, \frac{1}{16} respectively \).
hint: Consider the number of heads (X) where X can be 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4. Amount = X(1) - (4-X)(1.50).
solution_steps: Case 1: 4 Heads, 0 Tails. Amount = 4(1) = Rs 4. P(4H) = 4C4/16 = 1/16
Case 2: 3 Heads, 1 Tail. Amount = 3(1) - 1.50 = Rs 1.50. P(3H) = 4C3/16 = 4/16
Case 3: 2 Heads, 2 Tails. Amount = 2(1) - 2(1.50) = Rs -1. P(2H) = 4C2/16 = 6/16
Case 5: 0 Heads, 4 Tails. Amount = -4(1.50) = Rs -6. P(0H) = 4C0/16 = 1/16

question_plain: Check whether the following probabilities P(A) and P(B) are consistently defined: (i) P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.7, P(A ∩ B) = 0.6 (ii) P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.4, P(A ∪ B) = 0.8
question_latex:
Check whether the following probabilities P(A) and P(B) are consistently defined:
(i) \( P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.7, P(A \cap B) = 0.6 \)
(ii) \( P(A) = 0.5, P(B) = 0.4, P(A \cup B) = 0.8 \)
hint: Recall that P(A ∩ B) \leq P(A) and P(A ∩ B) \leq P(B). Also, P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B) must be \leq 1.
solution_steps: (i) P(A ∩ B) = 0.6. But P(A) = 0.5. Since the intersection cannot be greater than the probability of the individual event (0.6 > 0.5), it is not consistent.
Since 0.1 > 0 and all values are between 0 and 1, it is consistent.

question_plain: If E and F are events such that P(E) = 1/4, P(F) = 1/2 and P(E and F) = 1/8, find (i) P(E or F), (ii) P(not E and not F).

hint: Use De Morgan's Law: P(not E and not F) = 1 - P(E or F).
solution_steps: (ii) P(not E and not F) = P(E' ∩ F') = P(E ∪ F)' = 1 - P(E ∪ F).

question_plain: Events E and F are such that P(not E or not F) = 0.25, State whether E and F are mutually exclusive.
question_latex: Events E and F are such that \( P(E' \cup F') = 0.25, State whether E and F are mutually exclusive \).
correct_answer_plain: No, they are not mutually exclusive.
correct_answer_latex: No, they are not mutually exclusive.
hint: Mutually exclusive events must have P(E ∩ F) = 0.
solution_steps: By De Morgan's Law, P(E' ∪ F') = P(E ∩ F)' = 1 - P(E ∩ F).
Since P(E ∩ F) \neq 0, events E and F are not mutually exclusive.

question_plain: A box contains 10 red marbles, 20 blue marbles and 30 green marbles. 5 marbles are drawn from the box, what is the probability that (i) all will be blue? (ii) atleast one will be green?
question_latex: A box contains 10 red marbles, 20 blue marbles and 30 green marbles. 5 marbles are drawn from the box, what is the probability that (i) all will be blue? (ii) atleast one will be green?
hint: Total marbles = 60. Use combinations to select 5 marbles.
solution_steps: (i) All blue: Select 5 blue from 20 \to 20C5. P(all blue) = 20C5 / 60C5.
(ii) Atleast one green: 1 - P(no green). No green means selecting 5 from the 30 non-green (red and blue) \to 30C5. P(atleast one green) = 1 - (30C5 / 60C5).

question_plain: A die has two faces each with number '1', three faces each with number '2' and one face with number '3'. If die is rolled once, determine (i) P(2) (ii) P(1 or 3) (iii) P(not 3)
question_latex: A die has two faces each with number '1', three faces each with number '2' and one face with number '3'. If die is rolled once, \det ermine (i) \( P(2) \) (ii) \( P(1 \text{ or } 3) \) (iii) \( P(\text{not } 3) \)
hint: Total faces = 6. Count the occurrences of each number.
solution_steps: (i) P(2): There are three faces with '2'. P(2) = 3/6 = 1/2.
(ii) P(1 or 3): Two faces have '1' and one face has '3'. Total = 2 + 1 = 3. P(1 or 3) = 3/6 = 1/2.
(iii) P(not 3): 1 - P(3). One face has '3'. P(not 3) = 1 - 1/6 = 5/6.

visual_content.diagram_description: Non-standard die showing 6 faces: two faces with 1, three faces with 2, one face with 3.

question_plain: In a certain lottery 10,000 tickets are sold and ten equal prizes are awarded. What is the probability of not getting a prize if you buy (a) one ticket (b) two tickets (c) 10 tickets.
question_latex: In a certain lottery 10,000 tickets are sold and ten equal prizes are awarded. What is the probability of not getting a prize if you buy (a) one ticket (b) two tickets (c) 10 tickets.
hint: Calculate the probability of drawing only from the non-winning tickets.
solution_steps: Total tickets = 10,000. Prize tickets = 10. Non-prize tickets = 9,990.
(b) Buying 2 tickets: Select 2 from 9,990 / Select 2 from 10,000 = 9990C2 / 10000C2.
(c) Buying 10 tickets: Select 10 from 9,990 / Select 10 from 10,000 = 9990C10 / 10000C10.

question_plain: Out of 100 students, two sections of 40 and 60 are formed. If you and your friend are among the 100 students, what is the probability that (a) you both enter the same section? (b) you both enter the different sections?
question_latex: Out of 100 students, two \sec tions of 40 and 60 are formed. If you and your friend are among the 100 students, what is the probability that (a) you both enter the same \sec tion? (b) you both enter the different \sec tions?
hint: Total ways to choose 40 students for the first \sec tion is 100C40.
solution_steps: (a) Both in same \sec tion: Either both in 40-\sec tion (choose 38 others from 98 \to 98C38) or both in 60-\sec tion (choose 40 others from 98 \to 98C40).

question_plain: Three letters are dictated to three persons and an envelope is addressed to each of them, the letters are inserted into the envelopes at random so that each envelope contains exactly one letter. Find the probability that at least one letter is in its proper envelope.

solution_steps: Let letters be L1, L2, L3 and envelopes E1, E2, E3. Correct matches: (L1,E1), (L2,E2), (L3,E3).
Outcomes with at least one correct match: { (L1,L2,L3), (L1,L3,L2), (L3,L2,L1), (L2,L1,L3) } where order indicates position in E1, E2, E3.
Correct matches: 1-1-1 (1 way), 1-0-0 (3 ways). Total favorable = 4.

question_plain: If 4-digit numbers greater than 5000 are randomly formed from the digits 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7, what is the probability of forming a number divisible by 5 when (i) the digits are repeated? (ii) the repetition of digits is not allowed?
question_latex: If 4-digit numbers greater than 5000 are randomly formed from the digits 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7, what is the probability of forming a number divisible by 5 when (i) digits repeated? (ii) repetition not allowed?
hint: A number is divisible by 5 if it ends in 0 or 5.
solution_steps: (i) With repetition: Numbers > 5000 must start with 5 or 7. Total = 2 × 5 × 5 × 5 = 250.
Favorable (divisible by 5): Ends in 0 or 5. Ways = 2 × 5 × 5 × 2 = 100.
(ii) No repetition: Total numbers = (Starts with 5: 1 × 4 × 3 × 2) + (Starts with 7: 1 × 4 × 3 × 2) = 48.
Favorable: Ends in 0 (2 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 12) or ends in 5 (1 × 3 × 2 × 1 = 6). Total = 18.

question_plain: Which of the following are sets? Justify your answer. (i) The collection of all the months of a year beginning with the letter J. (ii) The collection of ten most talented writers of India. (iii) A team of eleven best-cricket batsmen of the world. (iv) The collection of all boys in your class. (v) The collection of all natural numbers less than 100. (vi) A collection of novels written by the writer Munshi Prem Chand. (vii) The collection of all even integers. (viii) The collection of questions in this Chapter. (ix) A collection of most dangerous animals of the world.
question_latex: Which of the following are sets? Justify your answer. (i) The collection of all the months of a year beginning with the letter J. (ii) The collection of ten most talented writers of India. (iii) A team of eleven best-cricket batsmen of the world. (iv) The collection of all boys in your class. (v) The collection of all natural numbers less than 100. (vi) A collection of novels written by the writer Munshi Prem Chand. (vii) The collection of all even integers. (viii) The collection of questions in this Chapter. (ix) A collection of most dangerous animals of the world.
correct_answer_plain: Sets: (i), (iv), (v), (vi), (vii), (viii). Not sets: (ii), (iii), (ix) - because they are not well-defined.
correct_answer_latex: Sets: (i), (iv), (v), (vi), (vii), (viii). Not sets: (ii), (iii), (ix) - because they are not well-defined.
hint: A set must be well-defined - it should be clear whether an element belongs to the collection or not
solution_steps: (i) SET - Months beginning with J are January, June, July. This is well-defined.
(ii) NOT A SET - 'Most talented' is subjective and not well-defined. Different people may have different opinions.
(iii) NOT A SET - 'Best' is subjective and not well-defined. Different people may disagree on who are the best.
(iv) SET - We can clearly identify all boys in a class. This is well-defined.
(v) SET - Natural numbers less than 100 are clearly defined: {1, 2, 3, ..., 99}.
(vi) SET - All novels by Munshi Prem Chand can be clearly identified. This is well-defined.
(vii) SET - Even integers {..., -4, -2, 0, 2, 4, ...} are clearly defined.
(viii) SET - Questions in this chapter can be clearly counted and identified.
(ix) NOT A SET - 'Most dangerous' is subjective and not well-defined.

question_latex: Write the following sets in roster form: (i) \( A = \{x : x \) is an integer and \( -3 \leq x < 7\} \) (ii) \( B = \{x : x \) is a natural number less than 6\( \} \) (iii) \( C = \{x : x \) is a two-digit natural number such that the sum of its digits is 8\( \} \) (iv) \( D = \{x : x \) is a prime number which is divisor of 60\( \} \) (v) \( E = \) The set of all letters in the word TRIGONOMETRY (vi) \( F = \) The set of all letters in the word BETTER

correct_answer_plain: (i) {x : x = 3n, n ∈ N and 1 ≤ n ≤ 4} (ii) {x : x = 2^n, n ∈ N and 1 ≤ n ≤ 5} (iii) {x : x = 5^n, n ∈ N and 1 ≤ n ≤ 4} (iv) {x : x is an even natural number} (v) {x : x = n², n ∈ N and 1 ≤ n ≤ 10}
correct_answer_latex: (i) \( \{x : x = 3n, n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } 1 \leq n \leq 4\} \) (ii) \( \{x : x = 2^{n}, n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } 1 \leq n \leq 5\} \) (iii) \( \{x : x = 5^{n}, n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } 1 \leq n \leq 4\} \) (iv) \( \{x : x \text{ is an even natural number}\} \) (v) \( \{x : x = n^{2}, n \in \mathbb{N} \text{ and } 1 \leq n \leq 10\} \)
hint: Identify the pattern in each set. Look for arithmetic sequences, geometric sequences, or powers
solution_steps: (i) Pattern: Multiples of 3. {x : x = 3n, n ∈ N and 1 \leq n \leq 4}
(ii) Pattern: Powers of 2. {x : x = 2^n, n ∈ N and 1 \leq n \leq 5}
(iii) Pattern: Powers of 5. {x : x = 5^n, n ∈ N and 1 \leq n \leq 4}
(iv) Pattern: All even natural numbers. {x : x is an even natural number} or {x : x = 2n, n ∈ N}
(v) Pattern: Perfect squares from 1 to 100. {x : x = n^{2}, n ∈ N and 1 \leq n \leq 10}

question_plain: List all the elements of the following sets: (i) A = {x : x is an odd natural number} (ii) B = {x : x is an integer, -1/2 < x < 9/2} (iii) C = {x : x is an integer, x² ≤ 4} (iv) D = {x : x is a letter in the word 'LOYAL'} (v) E = {x : x is a month of a year not having 31 days} (vi) F = {x : x is a consonant in the English alphabet which precedes k}
question_latex: List all the elements of the following sets: (i) \( A = \{x : x \) is an odd natural number\( \} \) (ii) \( B = \{x : x \) is an integer, \( -\frac{1}{2} < x < \frac{9}{2}\} \) (iii) \( C = \{x : x \) is an integer, \( x^{2} \leq 4\} \) (iv) \( D = \{x : x \) is a letter in the word 'LOYAL'\( \} \) (v) \( E = \{x : x \) is a month of a year not having 31 days\( \} \) (vi) \( F = \{x : x \) is a consonant in the English alphabet which precedes k\( \} \)
correct_answer_plain: (i) A = {1, 3, 5, 7, 9, ...} (infinite set) (ii) B = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} (iii) C = {-2, -1, 0, 1, 2} (iv) D = {L, O, Y, A} (v) E = {February, April, June, September, November} (vi) F = {b, c, d, f, g, h, j}
hint: For \inf inite sets, show pattern with '...'. For (ii) and (iii), check which integers satisfy the condition
solution_steps: (i) All odd natural numbers: A = {1, 3, 5, 7, 9, ...} (\inf inite set)
(iv) Distinct letters in LOYAL: D = {L, O, Y, A}
(v) Months without 31 days: E = {February, April, June, September, November}
(vi) Consonants before k: F = {b, c, d, f, g, h, j}
